Issues.Body:

Issues.Title: Allow whitelisting and blacklisting for scroll reset
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ feature request
Allow enabling/disabling scroll restoration on a route level

### Relevant Package
This feature request is for @angular/router

### Description
We are forced to set scroll restoration behaviour on the app level.

There are specific cases, where we actually wish to disable the behaviour.
In our case the data can change, and the layout is the same. We would like to keep the user's scroll position even though the route has changed.

Right now we have to drop using the default scrolling system and use our own. It's probably less efficient and won't get updated as much.

### Possible Solutions Considered
It could be solved a few different ways.

**1. Global Blacklist**

```ts
{ 
  anchorScrolling: 'enabled',
  scrollPositionRestoration: 'enabled',
  scrollPositionBlacklist: [{from: /^todo\/.*$/, to: /^todo\/.*$/}]
}
```

By allowing the `from` and `to`, you can provide a lot more flexibility and a very easy to reason about system at the global level. This is also a relatively straightforward implementation, without needing to introduce any other concepts or dependencies.

The downside to this implementation is that it would be very easy to update the route without updating the corresponding blacklist. It's not easy to understand the whole route logic without seeing the route.

**2. Route Option**
The ideal long-term solution (IMO) would be two new parameters on the `Route` definition for `scrollPositionRestoration` and `anchorScrolling`

The option would look something like.

```ts
{ path: '/todo/:id', scrollPositionRestoration: { value: 'enabled',  from : /todo\/.+/  } }
```

The positive to this is that it keeps things consistent for the global/local options. It also allows for extension to make it a async function in a future feature.

The downside is that it extends the already bloated `Route` options. It lacks the ability to define global cases that are a little more broad, creating repetition.

## Contributing
This is something I am willing to try and tackle, if given permission and we can agree on a strategy.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Allow whitelisting and blacklisting for scroll reset" (#30709)

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): correct timing of NgModuleFactory registration
Issues.Body:
Commit 0df719a46 introduced registration of NgModules with ids when compiled
with AOT, and f74373f2d corrected the timing to avoid issues with tree
shaking. Neither of these approaches were correct.

This commit fixes the timing to match View Engine and avoid tree shaking
issues, as well as fixes a bug with the registration of imported module ids.

A new Ivy-only test is added which verifies that modules get registered
correctly under real-world conditions.

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): module with providers are processed too early
Issues.Body:
Currently with Ivy, `ModuleWithProvider` providers are processed in order
of declaration in the `NgModule` imports. This technically makes makes
sense but is a potential breaking change as `ModuleWithProvider` providers
are processed after all imported modules in View Engine and the order
of multi-providers will therefore be different in Ivy (as with route definitions)

In order to keep the behavior of View Engine, the `r3_injector` is updated
to no longer process `ModuleWithProvider` providers egarly.

Resolves FW-1349

Issues.Title: Add preserveFragment/preserveQueryParams options for router/Route
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ feature request

### Relevant Package
This feature request is for @angular/router

### Description
It would great to have such an option to disable preserving parts of the route for a whole router or specific routes. The issue that I am currently facing is like so:
1) https://www.npmjs.com/package/angular-oauth2-oidc redirects to our main page with URI https://app.com#oidc_token_info
2) angular router starts to redirect to https://app.com/main:
```
{
		path: '',
		redirectTo: 'main',
		pathMatch: 'prefix',
		canActivate: [RouteGuard],
},
```
3) angular-oauth2-oidc resets hash part: `location.hash = ''`
4) angular router redirects to https://app.com/main#oidc_token_info because original URI contained this hash

The problem is I don't need and don't want this information in URI after redirect. It clutters the URI and can be a security issue if the user shares the link.

### Describe the solution you'd like
It would be great to have an option to set up this declaratively as with `router.navigate`
https://angular.io/api/router/NavigationExtras#preserveFragment
In this way, I would redirect after login to some specific URI with hash preservation disabled.

### Describe alternatives you've considered
I can manually redirect using `router.navigate` after login but I doubt that's expected use case for routing.

Issues.Title: Additional information on how to migrate to new ViewChild/ContentChild
Issues.Body:
# üìö Docs or angular.io bug report

### Description
From https://next.angular.io/guide/static-query-migration:

> Without the static flag, the compiler decided when each query would be resolved on a case-by-case basis. All @ViewChild/@ContentChild queries were categorized into one of two buckets at compile time: "static" or "dynamic".

But now we have to define this, and this is cool with me, but what if my code relied on a Query which, in one case, needs to be dynamic, and in another case, needs to be static?

Example:
- I have a base_validation component, which gets specialized in input_validation, select_validation, etc...
- The base_validation component keeps a link on a generic NgModel declared in each of the specialized components
- In "input_validation", the NgModel must be resolved statically
- In "select_validation", the NgModel must be resolved dynamically (i have to do some *ngIf magic there)

After fiddling with this for some time i found a way to make the new ViewChild act exactly like the previous version so that component logic refactoring will not (as far as my tests go) be required.

(Apparently i'm unable to format this decently...)

@ViewChild(NgModel, { static: false }) validationControl: NgModel;

@ViewChild(NgModel, { static: true }) set validationControl_static(comp: NgModel) {
    if (comp) { this.validationControl = comp; }
};

This way, apparently, you get the dynamic part of the ViewChild and you "manually" merge it with the static part. (also, setters on a dynamic ViewChild doesn't get fired for some reason).

I think this might be useful to add to the static-query-migration. At least it would have been useful for me :)

Cheers!

Issues.Title: fix(ng-update): do not always use double quotes for generated imports
Issues.Body:
Currently when someone uses single quote import declarations in
their project and the `ng update` migration for Material runs, the
Material imports are rewritten into multiple imports referring to
individual secondary entry-points, but the actual existing quote
style is ignored. This means that the linter can sometimes complain
after the migration has been performed.

Ideally we'd run the tslint fix task after the migration ran in order to
fix all lint rule failures which are specific to the given project, but this
is not a best-practice yet and we need to decide on the CLI-side whether
the CLI should automatically run the fixers after generator/migration
schematics ran. See: https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/14532

Unfortunately we can't do the same thing for the whitespace within
the `NamedImports` declaration because the whitespace for object
literal expressions is hard-coded. See:

https://github.com/microsoft/TypeScript/blob/6a559e37ee0d660fcc94f086a34370e79e94b17a/src/compiler/emitter.ts#L3796-L3797
(`emitObjectLiteralExpression` does not allow configuring the format flags)

Issues.Title: refactor(mdc-prototypes): do not mark components dirty in input setters
Issues.Body:
In order to make our component inputs which use boolean coercion more
consistent with other inputs which aren't declared through setters, we should
no longer call `markForCheck` within input setters as Angular automatically
runs change detection if input values are updated.

This breaks the programmatic usage of these inputs as Angular in that case
won't be able to run change detection (since it can't detect that the value
of the input changes).. though this is a more general problem with the
`OnPush` strategy as we can't have consistent behavior for programmatic
input updates without switching *every* input to a setter.

Instead, in order to still support programmatic input updates, we
_could_ expose a method that allows developers to mark the MDC
components as dirty. This is necessary so that developers which
_really_ need to update programmatically (e.g. through `ViewChild`)
can still update the componet to reflect the changes. The benefit is
that we don't need to convert every input to a setter w/ markForCheck
in order to make the OnPush inputs behavior consistent.

Related to COMP-170

**Note**: Removal of `markForCheck` as discussed in the last meeting and an additional proposal of adding a `markForCheck` method to components in order to still support programmatic input updates.
